DOC.HEAD: Kohl-Modrow Summit Produces Sheaf of Agreements
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Following are the agreements announced after Tuesday's summit between East German Premier Hans Modrow and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl: _ The two German states will negotiate a ``Treaty Community'' relationship, which would recognize the sovereignty of both nations and facilitate closer political and economic ties. _ An economic cooperation agreement has been signed and a joint committee established to determine how West German aid should be used to help East Germany recover and boost production. _ The East German government will open a pedestrian crossing through the Berlin Wall at the historic Brandenburg Gate before Christmas. _ Visa-free travel for West Germans and an end to the forced exchange of at least 25 marks ($14.50) per day will take effect on Dec. 24, instead of Jan. 1 as announced earlier. _ West Germans will be allowed to change their convertible West German marks at a rate of 1:3 for the non-convertible East marks after Jan. 1. All official exchanges had been fixed at 1:1 to date. _ East Germany will work to change regulations to allow all interested airlines to fly to West Berlin outside the Allied prescribed corridors. Only British, French and American airlines have been allowed to use the corridors to West Berlin's Tegel Airport. _ West German credit guarantees for exports to East Germany will be raised from 4.5 billion to 6 billion marks ($2.6 billion to $3.5 billion), to ensure delivery of goods to the economically strapped socialist state. _ West Germany's contribution to the East German communications network will be raised from 200 million to 300 million marks ($116 million to $173 million) annually, to rebuild the nation's telephone system.
